text: so Jenny of a new book out about Barack
Obama's mother Stanley on Dunham and
people don't know very much about her
beyond what the President himself has
written about her so what should people
know about her
well you're right people think of her as
simply the white woman from Kansas
that's about it
in fact she lived an extraordinarily
interesting and complicated life a woman
who at very young age married an African
at a time when there were laws in 24
states against interracial marriage she
became an anthropologist she was a
piping of a pioneer in the field of
microfinance except that people have
really thought about her they tend to
think about whether she was a good
mother or not a good mother and I think
that says a lot about our sense of
mothers given that you had he an absent
father yes she was not an the orthodox
model of a mother she took her son
abroad at age six to a country that was
in great upheaval she sent him back
alone at ten from Indonesia to Hawaii
she really made some decisions that many
Americans find difficult to swallow
these were complicated decisions as you
might understand you might imagine you
know juggling the very questions that
many of us juggle has how to make a
living how to get a decent education how
to get a good education for your child
when you're living in a place where the
schools are terrible now you write in
the book that it's striking sort of the
similarities between them and they just
similarities between them Barack Obama
and his mother so how were they alike
how are they not alike as he described
her himself to me he described her as as
quite disorganized in a way that spilled
over in his child right he is clearly
the opposite she lived as an expatriate
he made a decision to route himself in
Chicago there are many ways that they
are both both brave in a similar way and
yet they deviate in other choices and so
what was it like to go talk to the
President himself about his mother
I hadn't really even known if he was
going to talk to me but he did agree to
and I was struck by how frank he was he
was very comfortable talking about her
he spoke about her with both love and
affection but a certain kind of critical
distance as though he were now able to
see her at a remove almost as though
this was a person who had caused him a
certain amount of pain as a child which
he
he seems some highly-processed about his
parenting it did seem that way he said
he would not have wished that she
behaved differently or that they he'd
had a different childhood because the
underlying fact was that he had she
loved him so much and she had such
confidence in his gifts that it gave him
the kind of stability and strength of
character that he believes underlies a
lot of his cool and self-confidence that
many Americans find so mysterious in the
process of doing this book what was the
thing about her that most surprised you
everything I mean I never imagined that
an American president would have a
mother who had done the things that she
did she really makes us question many of
the assumptions we have about what's the
right way of doing things or the wrong
way because after all she did produce a
president
